text: [Music]
well I was brought up in Plymouth
Massachusetts which is an Old
Town uh a really Yankee
Incarnation and most of the black people
that I knew growing up looked and
sounded and talked just as I do which
may seem peculiar to many people but
that is part part of the local
inheritance I think we are as native
there as uh salt card or blueberries or
cranberries and that's how it is and the
term afro Saxon was uh coined by a
colleague of mine here not entirely as a
compliment but I have always taken it as
a rather apt description of the world in
which I grew up because my family were
very much conscious of our race I think
it could be said my mother was a race
woman she had a very high notion of our
race and I was never brought up to think
other otherwise for myself I remember
she once said you must always remember
you were descended from Kings well I
thought that was wonderful course she
meant African princes and African kings
and we could never document that I
suspect the time will come when the
truth will really be known but it's not
a small thing for little boy to grew up
thinking he is a descendant of Kings so
I never had any ego problems with my
identity but the culture even though I
was no doubt uh a descendant of Africans
the culture was a very Yankee uh New
England Puritan anglosaxon culture and I
took to it I absorbed it uh mainlined it
as you might say and that I think is
what my uh genial critic referred to
when he described me as the first afro
Saxon that he had ever
known now I think he meant by that that
I was lacking in sufficient uh readly
identifiable African or or American
black ethnic qualities that my speech
doesn't conform to what people think is
standard
africanamerican speech and that my
values seem to derive from the local
Countryside as opposed to uh a more
shall we say uh Southern or uh Afric
African-American identified ethos it
didn't help that I went to college in
Maine which was even more uh Central to
the uh uh Yankee myth than even Plymouth
itself and then of course I've spent all
my career here in Cambridge
Massachusetts at Harvard College which
is of course the institutional
expression of all of that so for better
or worse uh as that as the kids like to
say it is what it is I am what I am I am
what I am and uh it confuses people
which gives me great
pleasure she was a preacher's daughter
the only daughter of a prominent
preacher here in Cambridge at the turn
of the 19th century and she had a rather
Grand View of herself and hence of me
and I think I've inherited that but it
was full of all these to whom much is
given as much as expected handsome is as
handsome does all of the Victorian
virtues which she had I inherited I
think through my mother's milk and uh
didn't challenge them by and large I
accepted them uh her view was that great
things would be expected of me and I
must live into them there was no doubt
that uh the sun sha on me I was an only
child and uh therefore there were were a
set of uh expectations and obligations
and
responsibilities I must always do the
right thing whatever that was I must
always do my duty and since I was her
only child I was the object of her total
attention and that was considerable so
uh I regarded her as uh my best teacher
and my wisest counselor and in most
instances except for the odd moment of
teenage rebellion as my best friend she
was a great soul to
me I'm not altogether sure that that's
true she was a preacher daughter and
Preachers Daughters always have
ambiguous relationships toward the
clergy her father her papa to whom she
was devoted uh died at a very early age
in his 40s and I think she always blamed
the church for doing her father in he
worked too hard there were too many
rivals for his affection and his duties
so I'm not altogether sure she liked the
church I'm not even together sure she
liked the clergy but she liked me and
she thought it was a respectable
honorable calling and that I was well
suited to it so uh she rather enjoyed
being The Minister's mother and I think
expected me to make that calling a
useful one for her as well as for me in
a way I always thought my job was to
redeem the church which had disappointed
her and which had treated her father not
as well as she thought he should have
been treated I never knew my grandfather
so I never knew how accurate that
reading was but I certainly got that
impression
